Exhibit files are filed chronologically by date of installation. Exhibit panels of many of the larger exhibits are currently (August 2006) filed in large flat boxes on the exhibit shelves. See also scrapbooks and oversize.

Exhibits/1975/Long Time Residents of the Hartford Area

"Special Projects" include ventures that comprised several facets such as an exhibit, publication, and meeting program, or which didn't fall into any of these three categories.
Some of the folders in Box 28 are missing. They may have been refilled in a different place

Special Projects/2002/Greater Hartford Jewish Community History Project, funded by Zachs Family Foundation
Box 29: Special Projects/1995/Soviet Jewish World War II Exhibit/Jewish War Veterans
This project consisted of an exhibit and an oral history program and led to the Witness to War project carried out during the 2000s. Some tapes are related to the Witness to War project.
Nov. 2000 Betty Hoffman/ JFS citizenship class at Beth Israel
Box 30: Special Projects/2009/Hartford North End Project
This project consisted of a book that was the compilation of more that 150 memories from people growing up in Hartford's North End (predominately Jewish members of community but not exclusively)

Due to the large number of Witness to War materials, these boxes are numbered separately from the rest of the JHSGH collection.
Two boxes containing information on publicity and exhibits.

Witness to War: The Soviet Jewish Experience 1941-1945 was a major traveling exhibit conceived of and created by the JHSGH. The project involved the interviewing and videotaping of numerous Russian-Americans of the World War II generation. The project resulted in two end products: the traveling exhibit and a volume of Connecticut Jewish History dedicated to the topic. This collection contains the original videotapes, transcripts in both Russian and English, and administrative files related to the project.

Witness to War was coordinated by JHSGH Director Marsh Lotstein and Dr. Betty Hoffman, historian. The exhibit was designed by Harrison (Whitey) Jenkins. Jeffrey Mills designed the brochure and Diana McCain provided publicity services.
Special Projects/Witness to War, Box 1: Witness Transcripts
Special Projects/Witness to War/Transcripts/Russian/Murakovskiy, Israel Mura
Special Projects/Witness to War/Witnesses/Kogan, Hyman (Chaim)/Autobiography dictated to volunteers
Box 1a Special Projects/Witness to War/Transcripts/English Note: these files also contain release forms
Special Projects/Witness to War/Brochures and Flyers
Special Projects/Witness to War, Box 2: Miscellaneous
Special Projects/Witness to War, Box 3: Miscellaneous

Special Projects/Witness to War, Boxes 4 to 6: Videotapes Special Projects/1998/Witness to War/ Videotapes/Three large record center boxes of videotapes, now (July 2005) stored in archives room (where Farming and Immigration Collections are stored) under glass shelves.
Special Projects/Witness to War, Boxes 7: Miscellaneous
2 boxes of scrapbooks Publicity, exhibits and other scrapbooks
One box of manuscript material in Aisle 7A

Witness to War: The Soviet Jewish Experience 1941-1945 was a major traveling exhibit conceived of and created by the JHSGH. The project involved the interviewing and videotaping of numerous Russian-Americans of the World War II generation. The project resulted in two end products: the traveling exhibit and a volume of Connecticut Jewish History dedicated to the topic. This collection contains the original videotapes, transcripts in both Russian and English, and administrative files related to the project.

Witness to War was coordinated by JHSGH Director Marsh Lotstein and Dr. Betty Hoffman, historian. The exhibit was designed by Harrison (Whitey) Jenkins. Jeffrey Mills designed the brochure and Diana McCain provided publicity services.
